;湖南省将自己定位为中非贸易枢纽的努力正在取得成效水果，2023 年前四个月交易额同比增长 90.4%，达到 31.4 亿美元，创历史新高。

;

;民营企业带动增长，1471 家企业交易额达 200 亿元（28 亿美元）——根据长沙海关的数据，在此期间，湖南对非贸易总额的 90% 以上。

;

;今年到目前为止，湖南对非贸易的企业数量也处于历史最高水平。增长，与去年前四个月相比增加了 18%，达到 1,558 家。

;

;虽然湖南与非洲的贸易仅占中国贸易总额的 3.4%，但该省的成绩源于一系列举措旨在加强与非洲国家的贸易联系。

;

;习近平主席在 2021 年中非合作论坛上提出，中国中部的内陆省份第一个建立“绿色通道”以促进从非洲进口农产品塞内加尔达喀尔的中非合作。

;

;其中包括放宽与非洲国家的进出口规则、建立货币清算中心以及与非洲农业生产者的贸易协定。

;< h3>;中国各省沿着习近平的“绿色通道”奔向非洲;

;2023 年前四个月，非洲对湖南的农产品出口增长了 16.6 倍，达到 1.5 亿元人民币（2,132 万美元）更多产品，例如来自肯尼亚的鳄梨和来自卢旺达的干辣椒。

;

;湖南省政府表示，天然和合成橡胶以及食品的进口量“强劲”增长。

;< p>;根据中央政府的政策，湖南是支持在非洲进行商业投资以促进双向贸易的几个中国省份之一。中非商会去年报告称，尽管大流行对经济造成了影响，但浙江、广东、山东和江苏也出现了增长。

;

;但湖南也热衷于强调其与非洲大陆的历史联系 –包括其作为毛泽东出生地的地位，毛泽东为中国大力支持包括非洲在内的发展中国家的外交政策奠定了基础。

;

;近年来，省政府发布了一系列公告，推动这些深层次的发展根源，包括关于袁隆平的声明——毛泽东时代中国最杰出的植物科学家——他将杂交水稻的最佳成就带到了非洲，并在湖南度过了大部分工作生涯。

;

;该省的立法者通过了法规，以指导建设自由贸易区和非洲非资源性产品集散、交易、加工中心。他们还批准了针对非洲进口的“绿色通关”系统。

;

;还批准了从省会长沙到非洲主要航空枢纽的客运和货运网络扩展的法案，以及开发一条河流- 通往非洲主要港口的海运中转航线。

;

;2021年，湖南工业重镇株洲成立中非铁海快运公司，标志着中非联运通道迈出新步伐非洲经广东省南沙港。

;

;该通道主要用于运输粮食、种子、汽车零部件、化学品和工程机械，一期工程覆盖非洲11个海港和20条公路和公路。通往非洲大陆内陆的铁路。

;

;习近平在中非贸易和金融中扮演私营部门的角色

;

;当局还希望在亚的斯亚贝巴和长沙之间建立一条货运航线——由埃塞俄比亚航空公司估计年吞吐量将达到 17,000 吨货物——这将使湖南成为一个重要的中非贸易和物流枢纽。

;

;Lauren Johnston，南非国际经济研究所中非研究员约翰内斯堡的事务说，湖南与非洲有产业互补，也不靠近中国的沿海或陆地边界。

;

;“这样，在中国成功发展和促进经济繁荣的地方，它在某种程度上成为内陆非洲经济体的典范，”她说。

;

;中国各省如何控制与非洲的贸易

;

;约翰斯顿说湖南以其建设而闻名、铁路和重工业制造商——包括大型工业机械设备公司三一重工。

;

;“由于其广阔的河流网络，它拥有非常成熟且历史悠久的农业产业，并且不仅是 [Yuan ]中国绿色革命之父，发明了成功的杂交水稻，还有[联合国粮食及农业组织]现任负责人屈冬玉，”她说。

;

;约翰斯顿说，在建设方面、铁路运输、农业，湖南既有对非相关产业，又擅长农产品加工。

;

;非洲的发展，帮助中国自身实现粮食安全，”她说。

;

;鳄梨战略：非洲旨在如何重新平衡与中国的贸易

;

;今年到目前为止，大多数湖南的非洲贸易是与南非、尼日利亚和埃及进行的。资源丰富的南非占全省与非洲国家贸易总额的五分之一，与尼日利亚、埃及的贸易额同比分别增长182.5%和282.5%。

;

;优势产品出口在此期间，机电和劳动密集型产品激增。

;

;湖南向非洲出口了价值 62.2 亿元人民币（8.8 亿美元）的机电产品，同比增长 191.6%占全省对非洲国家出口总额的三分之一以上。

;

;纺织品、服装和其他劳动密集型产品出口增长 146.3%，达到 55.8 亿元人民币（7.9 亿美元）。高科技出口飙升至 8.8 亿元人民币（1.24 亿美元），比去年同期增长 144.4%。

;

;继肯尼亚鳄梨之后，赞比亚豆粕进入中国

; p>;该省正在关注 6 月达成更多贸易交易的前景，届时长沙将举办第三届中国-非洲经济贸易展览会——这是自 Covid-19 以来的第一次，也是第二次以完全面对面的形式举行。;

;官员们已经访问了多个非洲国家以推销该展会，该展会由长沙永久主办，并得到中国商务部贸易发展局的支持。

;

;2019 年的首届活动促成签署84项合作协议，总金额达208亿美元，涉及贸易、投资、基础设施、农业、制造、航空、旅游等领域。第二个在线论坛达成了价值 159.3 亿美元的交易。

;超过 5 亿年龄在 18 至 26 岁之间的 Z 世代工人现在已做好准备进入亚太劳动力市场，工作场所人口结构发生了翻天覆地的变化，同时工作的性质、意义和报酬在人工智能时代被分开、审查和重新组合。

;

;受到通货膨胀的挤压，有选择被大流行病淘汰，他们已经成为一代“骗子”。

;

;他们是内容制作者、电子商务企业家和食品卡车所有者，利用技术从事多种工作并创造利基市场，因为他们寻找新的技能、额外的收入和经济自由的一瞥。

;

;“他们太不了解了”：新加坡因定价过高而被淘汰的年轻单身人士反对人民行动党

;

;致Z 世代，没有“工作或生活”，他们每天都面临着有时令人沮丧的暴风雪般的警告，这些警告是关于快速老龄化社会可能付出的代价；逐渐减少的福利供应以及人工智能 (AI) 承诺的工作革命的风险和回报。

;

;虽然财务需求是大多数人的主要驱动力，尤其是在通货膨胀推高物价的情况下食物、电话和住宿——光靠金钱并不是动力。

;

;“许多 Z 世代现在几乎将副业视为他们实际职业道路的一部分，”新加坡职业策略师 Adrian Choo 说。

;

;审计公司德勤最近的一项调查发现，46% 的 Z 世代表示他们在全职工作之外还有第二份工作。

;

;部分原因是他们在大流行期间陷入了动荡的就业市场。

;

;“我认为 [Z 世代] 目前正处于从 [大学] 毕业的非常艰难的时期，因为通货膨胀和荒谬的生活成本，”他说Santor Nishizaki，洛杉矶的组织领导力专家。 “他们中的很多人实际上在大流行期间开始了副业，只是为了支付生活费用。”

;

;在德勤对来自 44 个国家的近 15,000 名 Z 世代进行的调查中，35% 的人表示他们最担心的是生活成本，51% 的受访者表示他们靠支票生活。

;

;但副业文化也存在风险：过度工作、压力以及不同的能力和承诺可能成为万事通。

;

;法律也可能并不总是站在骗子一边。

;

;“雇主通常会在合同中包含雇员Simmons & Simmons 香港的就业律师 Wendy Wong 说。

;

;“所以我认为对于那些年轻人来说，实际检查合同对他们来说非常重要......确保他们遵守规定，没有违反任何规定。”

;

;本周在亚洲采访了该地区的骗子，了解他们的希望、恐惧和为他们工作、为他们工作的决心。

;

; p>;

;

;

;Meg Rutherford 每周有 5 天是一名商业律师，但到了周末，她会在“宠爱派对”上为 4 至 14 岁的孩子做造型。

;

; 26岁的她做了两年半的律师，在新西兰克赖斯特彻奇的一家中型律师事务所工作了一年。但自去年与伴侣买房后，她觉得经济负担开始沉重。

;

;“现在物价比以往任何时候都高，毫无疑问，买房增加了我们的开支，甚至如果情况会好转，”她说。

;

;“寻求更多收入的想法也是因为我们即将进入经济衰退，而且目前的情况非常不确定...

;

;“我心想，‘我能做到’，”她说。 “建立起来并没有那么昂贵，而且我之前已经有过一些经验，所以作为我自己的企业重新开始是有意义的。”

;

;Rutherford 推出了一个 Instagram 页面来宣传她在 3 月举办了宠爱派对业务，为 4 至 14 岁的儿童提供家庭美甲、修脚、发型设计和其他服务。

;

;社交媒体是任何开始新业务的人的诱饵， Rutherford 说，并且一直是她扩大影响力的重要工具。

;

;“我可以做广告说我正在举办这些放纵派对，但除非有人通过照片和社交媒体帖子看到我提供的东西，那么就很难让人们与你互动，”她说。

;

;

;

;“对我来说，学业不是最重要的，”一位即将毕业的新加坡商学院学生说Chang Cho Yew，24 岁。“我想出去冒险，自己做点什么。”

;

;于是 PropUp 诞生了，这是一家制作宣传房地产视频的公司。

;

;PropUp Chang 说，这并不是他与合作伙伴的第一个想法，但在经历了几次挫折和失败的尝试后，他们终于找到了可以坚持的东西。

;

;“我们今天是一家房地产视频制作公司，但当我创办了这家公司，我们试图做其他事情，比如在营销中 [利用] 虚拟现实，”他说，并补充说，他花了很长时间才为自己开辟了一个利基市场。

;

;没有企业Z 世代的阶梯——他们想通过影响力赚钱

;

;Chang 面临的最严峻挑战之一是必须兼顾学业和工作，这导致他的平均成绩受到打击，促使他考虑休学一年。

;

;但 Chang 支持自己在生意上做得很好，不仅是为了额外的收入，也是为了在这个城市国家的竞争中更上一层楼就业市场。

;

;“我让自己摆脱了激烈的竞争。我让自己摆脱了与一群争夺同一份工作的本科生的竞争，”他说。 “钱总是有的，只要你能与人交流，就能卖东西。”

;

;现在 Chang 不想停留在 PropUp 上，他有几个新的商业想法。他说，这意味着他甚至可能辍学。

;

;

;

;25 岁的 Rizky 是印度尼西亚万隆市一所中学的戏剧老师，他说他的真实想法激情在别处。

;

;“我想做一份有创意的工作，并利用我的（视觉艺术）学位，”他说。

;

;但在收到图形设计工作拒绝后担任了将近一年的角色后，他决定是时候换档并找到一份稳定的收入了。他在当地一所中学找到了一份教戏剧艺术的工作。

;

;“我父亲去世了，我母亲靠做餐饮生意赚取微薄收入，”Rizky 说，并要求路过他的名字，因为他的工作场所不鼓励第二职业。

;

;“我需要一份稳定的薪水来帮助我的家人，尤其是帮助支付我姐姐的学费。”

;

;但为了确保他的初恋没有失去，Rizky 开始在 Fiverr 和 Upwork 等网站上从事自由图形设计工作，设计传单和徽标以及制作插图，获得 10 美元到 30 美元的报酬。

;

;Rizky 的教学工作每月收入约 300 万印尼盾（200 美元）。尽管自由职业的工作是断断续续的，但 Rizky 说，即使每个月多赚一点钱也能起到很大的作用。

;

;“最近所有东西的价格似乎都在上涨，”他说。

;

;在学校放假期间，Rizky 从事自由职业，还参与了他朋友的婚纱摄影业务。

;

;虽然这份全职平面设计工作仍然遥遥无期，但 Rizky 并没有放弃，他的职业希望被推迟了，但并未被否定。

;

;“我很高兴它在某种程度上仍然是我生活的一部分，”他说。

;

;

;

;马来西亚人约书亚·巴塞洛缪 (Joshua Bartholomew) 今年 22 岁，梦想成为一名创作型歌手。目前，他在小型音乐节、酒吧和偶尔的婚礼上演奏翻唱歌曲，穿插他的原创歌曲。

;

;但对于朝九晚五的他，他在 Kota 的一家音乐商店担任销售代表京那巴鲁，马来西亚婆罗洲沙巴州的首府。

;

;能够将自己的音乐作为副业来追求既有趣又在某种程度上获得经济回报。

;

;“激情是其中的一部分，赚取额外的零用钱......它支付了我的一些账单，所以我不会破产，”他说。

;

;但是，他承认下班后急于准备演出可能会很累，尤其是因为他必须主要靠自己处理从促销到试音的所有事情，但他觉得如果这有助于将他的音乐带给更广泛的听众，那是值得的。

;

;Bartholomew 说社交媒体有也是确保演出和宣传他过去现场表演的歌曲和视频以建立追随者的不可或缺的工具。

;

;但他认为他的真正的副业不会很快取代他的日常工作。

;

;“我认为自己将来会更频繁地这样做，但老实说，我不会将其视为全职工作，”巴塞洛缪说。

;

;

;

;当新加坡正处于大流行期间时，28 岁的 Vanessa Neo 和 27 岁的 Calvina Thenderan 决定走出他们的舒适区并尝试一些新事物：开始他们自己的在线家居用品业务。

;

;这两个朋友是在一家跨国公司结识的，当时 Neo 提出了在 2021 年合作开展家居用品业务的想法，Thenderan 同意了。经过数月的市场调研和准备，他们于去年 4 月推出了 Hom。

;

;Hom 仍在发展中，但年轻的创业者已开始与其他品牌合作并出现在快闪店中。

;

;在整个过程中，Neo 继续担任全球品类专家的日常工作，而 Thenderan 则担任业务总监。这是一个艰难的平衡行为。

;

;Thenderan 说，他们两人都在努力兼顾各自的职责，导致精疲力竭。

;

;“这有点令人震惊，因为我们的公司在过去一年左右的时间里，工作变得更加紧张，那时候我们也开始了 Hom，”她说，并补充说两人不得不牺牲时间在业余爱好以及与家人和朋友的相处上。

;

;然后，他们决定从容应对这段经历，并将其转化为积极的事情。

;

;Neo 表示，从那以后，他们开始在公司的 Instagram 页面上分享“#WellnessWednesday”帖子，并与一家心理健康协会合作新加坡，每笔销售额向协会捐赠 1 新元。

;

;对他们来说，这项业务是一个充满激情的项目，也是培养他们创业精神的一种方式，但目前没有计划让 Hom 成为他们的全职工作

;

;“有很多事情需要考虑，比如当你的热情成为你的主要工作时，它肯定会从中获得乐趣，”Neo 说。

;新加坡流行歌手孙燕姿和她的歌曲在中国社交媒体平台上走红在人工智能生成的她声音副本的推动下，人们的兴趣激增。

;

;自 2000 年发行首张专辑“燕子”以来，孙（又名孙燕子）积累了在中国大陆和香港拥有庞大的粉丝群。

;

;她还赢得了许多荣誉，包括台湾著名的金曲奖。

;

;她在 QQ 音乐应用程序上拥有 400 万中国粉丝作为最著名的流行音乐平台之一，Sun 的歌曲《我想念的、遇见的和开始明白的》都获得了超过 900 万的点赞。

;

;最近，尽管已经六年没有发行一首歌曲

;

;在各大社交媒体平台上，AI-孙燕子AI生成的账号凭借其强大的模仿能力吸引了大批听众。不仅是 Sun 的声音，还有她独特的呼吸声。

;

;AI 账户涵盖了广泛的知名流行音乐，包括周杰伦的发如雪和南拳妈妈的雨天 – 全部来自台湾.

;

;一段翻唱《发如雪》的视频在哔哩哔哩平台上的点击量已超过200万。

;

;甚至有人戏称AI假人是“最勤奋的歌手” 2023 年国语音乐界”，因为他们具有在短时间内制作大量音乐的非凡能力。

;

;同时，“孙燕姿成为第一个被 AI 取代的音乐人”的话题标签已经成为

;

;然而，人工智能“表演者”并不适合所有人，尤其是 Sun 的粉丝。

;

;有人评论说：“这听起来很假。模仿孙燕子2001年左右的声调，那时候周杰伦的《发如雪》还没有上映。它可以模仿她的声音，但不能模仿她的现场表演，”另一位补充说。

;

;5月22日，孙在网上发表了一篇发自内心但又沉稳的帖子。

;

;“我的粉丝正式切换了并承认我确实是“冷门歌手”，而我的AI角色是当前的热门财产。我的意思是真的，你怎么和一个每隔几分钟就推出新专辑的人打架，”她说。

;

;承认人工智能已经重塑了广泛的行业并直接提到了这一现象，她补充说：“我们一直坚信的任务；思想或意见的形成是机器人无法复制的，这超出了他们的能力范围的想法，现在是威胁成千上万人类创造的工作的迫在眉睫的事情。法律，医疗，会计，现在，唱一首歌。

;

;“在这无边无际的存在海洋中，一切皆有可能，一切都不重要，我认为这将是思想的纯净，成为真正的自己这就足够了，”这位歌手总结道。

;

;AI 与孙燕姿的讨论揭示了此类技术在音乐行业中的双刃剑含义。

;

;同时加油在音乐创作的同时，人工智能也引发了对版权侵权的担忧。

;

;“当人工智能‘歌手’翻唱歌曲时，它可能会潜在地侵犯原创艺术家的权利，以及原创词曲作者和歌手的权利。唱片制作人，”天元律师事务所合伙人李云凯告诉《早报》。

;

;“无论是 AI 翻唱孙燕姿本人还是其他艺术家的歌曲，都涉及类似的版权侵权问题，”李说。< /p>;

;另外，如果平台为AI翻唱版设立专门的内容版块，直接与创作者分享收益，那么一旦发生侵权，平台也将与创作者共同承担相应的法律责任。 .

;

;2023 年 4 月 11 日，国家互联网信息办公室发布了题为《生成式人工智能服务管理办法》的政策文件草案，该文件被视为对人工智能可能的监管框架的探索。

;

;然而，许多问题仍未解决。

;

;“在AI音乐领域，现行法律仅对在世个体的声音权提供保护。如果用户利用已故名人的声音翻唱相关歌曲，这种使用的合法性仍然不确定，”李说。

;

;“例如，如果利用人工智能技术学习贝多芬的作曲风格并创作贝多芬第十交响曲，是否构成侵权，是现有法律规定无法明确回答的问题。”他补充道。

;;

;香港陷入困境的国泰航空需要大量重建工作来修复其破败不堪的局面形象，但也必须让员工做得更好，让他们感到自豪，公司大使不仅仅是员工，品牌和公共关系专家说。

;

;由于该市的旗舰航空公司卷入了涉及三人的歧视丑闻，因为 -解雇了空乘人员，专家们表示，虽然这三人树立了一个坏榜样，但并非所有员工都是这样，如果存在这种倾向，管理层也必须反思其角色，而不仅仅是暗示它与适当的培训有关。

;

;他们说，这与应该渗透到整个组织的企业文化有关，每个人都意识到他们所代表的品牌。

;

;飞行风险：解决香港国泰航空飞行员的不满

; h3>;

;周日，在成都飞往香港的航班上，一名说普通话的乘客指责三名空乘人员嘲笑乘客的英语能力，这让国泰航空陷入了丑闻。

;

;该乘客发布了自己的声音周一，内地社交媒体平台小红书上有一段空姐对话的录音，其中一位说：“如果你不能说‘毯子’，你就不能拥有它。”

;

;国泰航空的社交媒体账号已被评论泛滥，主要来自愤怒的大陆用户，贬低其服务标准。

;

;在事件报告出现后不到 48 小时，首席执行官林兆波周二晚间宣布，三名船员已被解雇后，他发誓要成立一个跨部门的工作组，以改善公司“客户至上”的文化。

;

;周三，他还用普通话向受影响的乘客和公众道歉，这是该公司第四次表达三天后后悔。

;

;行政长官李家超也表达了对事件的愤怒和失望，要求得到答复，并称这损害了香港的声誉。

;

;在一份内部文件中Lam 在周四发给所有员工的备忘录中表示，该事件反映了“我们需要解决的更深层次的问题”，该航空公司“必须谦虚反思，深刻审视我们的文化并采取具体措施”来扭转其形象。;

;研究危机管理的中国大学新闻与传播学院副教授 Kaman Lee 周五表示，丑闻表明不止一个问题困扰着公司。

;

;“这不是公共关系问题。这是一个企业问题，”李说，并指出国泰航空的形象和声誉近年来已经恶化。

;

;香港的国泰航空歧视丑闻：为什么机组人员表现如此糟糕？

;

;相反除了只关注前线员工是否接受过培训，Lee 表示，公司应该调查员工无法提供专业服务的原因。

;

;“为什么会发生这样的不专业事件？是不是涉及很多因素？”她说。 “这是招聘问题……还是为什么我们不能很好地培训员工？”

;

;Lee 补充说：“管理层需要让员工感到他们受到尊重，并且有支持他们的渠道。我们是否需要在薪资和福利方面改善员工待遇……以及如何让员工无忧无虑地工作。”

;

;她指出，这些都是有助于提高员工绩效的因素。

;< p>;“如果一家公司未能让员工心甘情愿地成为[公司]大使，那么这一定表明存在一些问题，”她说。

;

;为了提升其公众形象，国泰航空也应该她说，就跟进程序的效率和透明度而言，在处理危机和投诉方面始终如一。

;

;当地广告公司饿了么数码的董事 Rudi Leung Chi-sing 说，这次失败表明它确实做到了如果不对员工付出多少努力，无论航空公司在广告上投入多少。

;

;梁说，国泰的回应可能“过于抱歉”，这可能会“严重影响”内部士气。< /p>;

;“我们所知道的只是录音中发生的事情，我们不知道中间发生了什么，例如与客户的互动以及所涉及的情绪，”他说。

;

;“在处理这件事时，国泰就干脆下跪，可见没有考虑到员工的士气。”

;

;梁振英说，国泰不可能阻止这股洪流。互联网投诉，公司应该保持冷静，直接与相关客户打交道。

;

;“中国是一个大国，你无法应对所有的舆论，”他说。 “人若不服，多道歉三句也没用。可以没完没了。”

;

;国泰将加紧挽救声誉，将“虚心反思”丑闻

;

;他补充称，为挽救声誉，国泰只能“走Leung 说，通过向来自不同国家的乘客展示其空乘人员对乘客的尊重来“谈话”。

;

;从管理的角度来看，高管们应该始终在立即指责之前了解情况。

;

;中国大学航空政策与研究中心的袁志乐表示，国泰航空的反应在损害控制方面“迅速有效”，但从长远来看，有些问题必须妥善解决。

;

;“首先，国泰航空需要在中国大陆重塑形象，重新赢得当地客户的信任。其次，除了审查其服务协议和培训流程外，更重要的是要加强其以客户为中心的企业文化，”他说。

;

;“第三，领导层提高员工素质也很重要”

;

;Yuen 表示，由于劳动力短缺，疫情过后全球航空业的服务质量出现下降。

;

;“鉴于形势严峻，为员工建立一个协作和相互尊重的工作场所变得至关重要，”他说。

;

;香港平等监管机构警告国泰员工可能违反了歧视法

;

;与此同时，在国泰航空服务了八年的安迪*表示，他和他的同事认为国泰航空对事件的处理过于“突然”和“极端”。

;

;“即使这只是一种行为，[管理层] 可以花更多时间进行调查，这样人们就会知道他们确实试图了解情况和相关人员，”他说。

;

;“一切都发生得太快了。这给人的感觉是，他们试图给空乘人员一个例子，并迅速结束丑闻。”

;

;他说，自丑闻发生以来，他的同事们的士气变得低落，其中一些人甚至“害怕”去上班。

;

;“他们害怕自己会说错话并被记录下来，然后突然被解雇，”他说。 “感觉就像我们没有受到保护，很容易被解雇和替换。”

;

;他补充说，同事之间甚至谈话都感到不安，因为担心有人可以记录谈话内容，并表示担心这种情况可能引发wave of resignations.

;

;Andy said the ability to speak Mandarin was not required for all flight attendants as some were not Chinese, but he believed the airline might provide optional training in the language in future.

;

;He said when serving passengers who looked Asian, it was common practice for Cathay flight attendants to speak English before using other languages and observe their reactions.

;

;“If I speak Mandarin with a Japanese passenger, it may also count as discrimination,” he said.

;

;But Andy noted that it also depended on flight attendants' personal experience when speaking in different languages as some might be able to differentiate passengers from various countries after years of service .

;

;Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific tries to defuse insult scandal as union blasts management

;

;Cathay's cabin crew union on Wednesday expressed regret over the incident but said morale was at an all-time low, with the airline facing a manpower shortfall despite an increased workload and reduced pay.

;

;The union also urged the company to address the cause of the problem and rebuild a reasonable and safe work environment to improve staff morale.;

;But the carrier on Thursday issued a statement saying the company did not condone, support or agree with the union's position on the matter.

;

;*Name changed at interviewee's request.

; Sat, 27 May 2023 08:50:02 +0800 How Hong Kong can give the world reasons to fall back in love with ithttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3221721/how-hong-kong-can-give-world-reasons-fall-back-love-it?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.27 08:15;
;;

;Hong Kong is at a crossroads. The city needs to completely rethink its role globally and see how it can reinvent its brand and the way it is perceived.多年来，香港作为居住、职业或度假胜地的声誉不断恶化。 We must change this for the better to be internationally competitive.

;

;We have world-class infrastructure, gorgeous beaches, beautiful mountains and glittering skyscrapers all within 1,100 sq km. As many major cities struggle with structural issues, with high taxes and crime topping the list, Hong Kong is still a safe, well-connected, vibrant and dynamic place to live, work and visit.

;

;So how do we change the narrative and present the new Hong Kong? I believe the answer is to focus on becoming an international lifestyle centre, in parallel with our role as a global financial centre. If Hong Kong is to successfully attract new talent, create a family office hub and remain internationally competitive, it needs to offer a lifestyle that the world desires.

;

;Pre-pandemic, in 2018, Hong Kong had a record 65 million visitors, of which 51 million were from mainland China. Now, in a post-pandemic world, we should be more ambitious. We need to keep and grow our mainland visitor numbers, but we must also find compelling reasons to attract regional and international visitors. Vital to our success will be to think more holistically and strategically.

;

;Consider entertainment. Jay Chou's series of concerts at the Central Harbourfront this month sold out, attracting fans not just from Hong Kong and the mainland, but also Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia. Hong Kong needs to become a must-stop destination when global artists tour Asia. At the same time, we must coordinate with major business and cultural events to attract the right visitor demographics and create win-win attractions.

;

;Sports must be also key. The Hong Kong Sevens rugby tournament was part of our announcement to the world that the city is getting back to business after the pandemic. We have the new Kai Tak stadium opening in 2024 that will seat 50,000 people. We should be working strategically with football nations now to attract world-class teams to play invitation matches. Imagine the interest we would create regionally if Manchester City played Inter Milan for a Champions League rematch in Hong Kong?

;

;We are getting back into the swing of hosting world-class golf and tennis tournaments as part of the international circuit. Looking at golf specifically, the very last thing our government should be doing is eroding these lifestyle assets. We will lose the opportunity to develop our local talent and drive away international visitors.

;

;Aside from entertainment and sports, art and culture are also key ingredients for an international lifestyle centre. The M+ museum of visual culture and the Palace Museum are our new treasures. How can we leverage them further? We already host the wildly successful Art Basel, Hong Kong International Film Festival and numerous trade fairs.

;

;Hong Kong now needs to further promote and create regular, popular activities with our international counterparts. Think the likes of Le French May, Oktoberfest and the Thai Songkran Festival to establish Hong Kong as genuinely Asia's World City.

;

;As we work with our international partners, wine-and-dine diplomacy must also be high on our international lifestyle centre agenda. Thanks to our zero-tax environment, Hong Kong has become a wine hub. The government should now be imaginative and consider making Hong Kong a whisky hub and eliminating the taxes, in particular for rare whisky auctions.

;

;So where to go from here? I see three priorities. First, government and business must come together and design a sustainable, long-term plan to deliver the international lifestyle centre objective. Second, we need to create and give resources to a team dedicated to implementing the plan led by a newly appointed global Hong Kong brand ambassador.

;

;Super-connector brands like Cathay, Lee Kum Kee are Hong Kong's superpower

;

;Third, we must do a much better job of changing perceptions and getting Hong Kong back on the world map as a lifestyle and experience destination, simultaneously removing all the erroneous and damaging reputational baggage that persists.

;

;Hong Kong has the potential to regain its position as an iconic global destination. We just need to give people reasons to fall back in love with us.

;US authorities have arrested two suspected Chinese government agents in connection with an alleged plot by Beijing to disrupt and ultimately topple the exiled anti-communist Falun Gong spiritual movement.

;

;John Chen and Lin Feng were charged in an indictment unsealed on Friday with scheming to revoke a New York-based Falun Gong organisation's tax-exempt status and paying bribes to an undercover officer posing as a US tax agent.

;

;The undercover officer recorded multiple conversations with Chen, and investigators obtained a wire tap to record phone calls in which Chen and Feng discussed instructions they purportedly received from Chinese government officials, prosecutors said.

;

;In one recording, prosecutors said, Chen referred to Chinese government officials as akin to “blood brothers” and, in another, he said Beijing would be “very generous” in rewarding the undercover officer's help cracking down on Falun Gong's non-profit status.

;

;Chen, a 70-year-old US citizen, and Feng, a 43-year-old lawful permanent resident, are charged with acting as unregistered agents of a foreign government, bribing a public official and conspiracy to commit international money laundering.

;

;Chen and Feng were both born in China but now live in the Los Angeles area, where they were arrested on Friday. Information on an initial court appearance or lawyers who could speak on their behalf was not immediately available.

;

;Messages seeking comment were left with the Chinese embassy in Washington and with the Falun Gong movement.

;

;China banned the Falun Gong movement in 1999, classifying it as an evil cult and one of the “Five Poisons”, or chief threats to its rule. Since then, Falun Gong practitioners have found refuge at a 400-acre compound called Dragon Springs in upstate New York.

;

;Chinese cult buster who targeted Falun Gong faces corruption probe

;

;In the US, the Falun Gong movement is known mostly for its ties to Shen Yun, a touring performing arts group, and The Epoch Times, a newspaper that has been marketed as an alternative to traditional US media while also coming under fire for amplifying misinformation and conspiracy theories.

;

;The Justice Department has made a series of prosecutions in recent years to disrupt China's efforts in the US to identify, locate and silence pro-democracy activists and others who are openly critical of Beijing's policies. Such practices by foreign governments are known as “transnational repression”.

;

;“The Chinese government has yet again attempted, and failed, to target critics of the [People's Republic of China] here in the United States,” Attorney General Merrick B. Garland said in a statement.

;

;The US, Garland added, will “continue to investigate, disrupt, and prosecute” China's efforts to “silence its critics and extend the reaches of its regime onto US soil”.

;

;In seeking to undermine Falun Gong, federal prosecutors allege, Chen and Feng's urged the Internal Revenue Service to revoke the organisation's non-profit tax status. In a whistle-blower complaint to the tax agency in February, Chen described Falun Gong as a “gigantic mega cult” – echoing language China's government uses to describe the movement.

;

;Chen and Feng then turned to the undercover officer to make sure the IRS acted on the complaint, offering a US$50,000 reward – and handing over US$5,000 in cash as a down payment – if the tax agency conducted an audit, prosecutors said.

;

;Chen met the officer at a restaurant north of New York on May 14, prosecutors said. A few days later, the officer sent Chen a letter on fake IRS letterhead that stated the agency had opened a case on Falun Gong, prosecutors said.

;

;Chen relayed the news to Feng in a wire tapped phoned conversation, indicating that he was planning to update Chinese government officials on their progress, prosecutors said.

;

;US arrests 2 suspected of running Chinese 'secret police station' in New York

;

;Chen and Feng's arrest comes a month after the Justice Department charged two men with establishing a secret police station in New York on behalf of the Chinese government.

;

;Around the same time, federal prosecutors charged about three dozen officers with China's national police force with using social media to harass dissidents inside the US.

;

;In 2020, the Justice Department charged more than a half-dozen people with working on behalf of the Chinese government in a pressure campaign aimed at coercing a New Jersey man wanted by Beijing into returning to China to face charges.

; Sat, 27 May 2023 07:50:02 +0800 Killer whales damage boats in Spanish, Portuguese waters in puzzling new behaviourhttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/europe/article/3222011/killer-whales-damage-boats-spanish-portuguese-waters-puzzling-new-behaviour?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.27 06:58;

;A pod of killer whales repeatedly rammed a yacht in the Strait of Gibraltar this week, damaging it enough to require Spanish rescuers to come to the aid of its four crew members.

;

;It was the latest episode in a perplexing trend in the behaviour of orcas populating the Atlantic coast of the Iberian Peninsula that has left researchers searching for a cause.

;

;Spain's Maritime Rescue service said that killer whales repeatedly ran into the Mustique, a 20-metre (65-foot) vessel sailing under a UK flag, late on Wednesday, rendering its rudder inoperative and cracking its hull. Spanish rescuers needed to pump out seawater before towing her to safety.

;

;The alert reached the Spanish service via their British counterparts, who had relayed on the distress call, the Spanish service said. A helicopter and a rescue boat were deployed to help the damaged boat to dock in Barbate.

;

;This was the 24th such incident registered by the service this year. The service did not provide data from last year.

;

;But the Atlantic Orca Working Group, a team of Spanish and Portuguese marine life researchers who study killer whales near the Iberian Peninsula, says that these incidents were first reported three years ago. In 2020, the group registered 52 such events, some of which resulted in damaged rudders. That increased to 197 in 2021 and to 207 in 2022.

;

;The killer whales seem to be targeting boats in a wide arc covering the western coast of the Iberian Peninsula, from the waters near the Strait of Gibraltar to Spain's northwestern Galicia.

;

;According to the group, these killer whales are a small group of about 35 whales that spend most of the year near the Iberian coast in pursuit of red tuna. The so-called Iberian orcas average from five to 6½ metres (16-21 feet) in length, compared to the orcas of Antarctica which can reach nine metres (29½ feet).

;

;Killer whales off US west coast keep dying: Chinese-US study finds out why

;

;There have been no reports of attacks against swimmers. The interactions on boats seem to stop once the vessel becomes immobilised.

;

;Biologist Alfredo López, of the University of Aveiro and member of the research group, said that the incidents are rare – and enticingly odd.

;

;“In none of the cases that we have been able to see on video have we witnessed any behaviour that could be considered aggressive,” López said by phone on Friday.

;

;“They appear calm, nothing at all like when they are on the hunt.”

;

;López said that while the cause of the behavioural turn is unknown, his group has identified 15 individual whales that are involved in the incidents.

;

;He said that 13 are young whales, which could support the hypothesis that they are playing, while two are adults, which could support a competing theory that the behaviour is the result of some traumatic event with a boat.

;

;In either case, he said the whales are showing once again that they are social animals.

;

;“Orcs are animals with their own culture,” he said. “They transmit information to one another.”

;Two Democratic members of the US Congress have introduced a federal bill that would pre-empt American state laws restricting property ownership by citizens from China and other countries considered “foreign adversaries”.

;

;Offered in response to backlash against such laws, the bill is meant to address “real property discrimination” and pre-empts any US state or territory that “prohibits or otherwise restricts the purchase by an individual of real property … based on the citizenship of the purchaser”.

;

;“Real property” is often defined as land, buildings, fixtures and all other improvements to land.

;

;Introduced on Thursday by Al Green of Texas and Judy Chu of California, the bill comes weeks after Florida Governor Ron DeSantis signed into law legislation that prohibits Chinese citizens, except permanent residents and non-tourist-visa holders, from owning any property in Florida.

;

;Green and Chu's bill authorises the US attorney general to enforce the pre-emption, and says that individuals harmed by any such discriminatory state law may bring a civil action against the state and seek remedies.

;

;Florida's law, which also targets individuals and entities from six other “foreign adversaries”, is now being challenged in federal court by a group of Chinese residents and a real estate brokerage firm.

;

;“While these countries may be competitors or adversaries of the US, such provisions unnecessarily vilify persons lawfully within our country and exacerbate already heightened hostility towards ethnic minorities, in particular persons of Asian descent,” said Green, who like Chu, belongs to the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus.

;

;Green and Chu's bill also comes as the Louisiana legislature considers a bill that would restrict “foreign adversaries” and individuals connected to them from leasing or acquiring property. The bill passed the state's House of Representatives on Tuesday by a vote of 78-22.

;

;Judicial scrutiny could sink new Florida law banning Chinese property ownership

;

;Like Florida and other states considering similar bills, Louisiana lawmakers have seen their efforts questioned and have removed some of their legislation's harshest restrictions on ownership by individuals.

;

;Valerie Hodges, a Louisiana state congresswoman and the bill's sponsor, said it was meant to target “corporations who are trying to buy critical infrastructure”.

;

;Regardless of such bills' intended target, Asian-American groups have voiced concern about their broader implications.

;

;The proposed federal bill garnered the endorsement of 28 Asian-American groups on Thursday.

;

;Sandra Leung, president of the National Asian Pacific American Bar Association, called the initiatives by state lawmakers “ill-advised” and said they “eerily recall ancient alien land laws, which were enacted over a hundred years ago that barred Asian immigrants from owning land”.

;

;Asian-Americans should prepare for more hate, committee warns

;

;“Such laws belong in the dustbin of history,” she added.

;

;Bob Jarvis, a law professor at Florida-based Nova Southeastern University, said the proposed federal law would make it easier for individuals who wish to claim harm from relevant state laws “to prove standing in federal court”.

;

;Jarvis added that it would also send a signal to federal courts on how to rule in situations involving similar discriminatory laws, including those prohibiting foreigners from leasing, which is not addressed by Green and Chu's bill.

;

;But the legislation is not strictly necessary from a legal perspective, he said, as “the laws the states are passing are prohibited by the US Constitution and statutes like the federal Fair Housing Act”.

;

;“What this proposed federal law does do is express its supporters' opposition to what states like Florida are doing.”

; Sat, 27 May 2023 06:50:02 +0800 Ding Xuexiang sets fast pace for China’s hi-tech drive in another sign of new rolehttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/politics/article/3221950/ding-xuexiang-sets-fast-pace-chinas-hi-tech-drive-another-sign-new-role?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;China's first ranking vice-premier, Ding Xuexiang, has called for the country to speed up its technological innovation, signalling his new role in Beijing's hi-tech drive in the face of headwinds from Washington and its allies.

;

;“[We must] perfect the system of technology innovation, optimise distribution of resources for innovation, strengthen infrastructure building for science and technology, and enhance the overall efficacy of the country's innovation system,” he said.

;

;Speaking at Thursday's opening ceremony of the Zhongguancun Forum in Beijing, Ding said Beijing would support the deep integration of research and production and step up intellectual property protection to support innovation.

;

;The remarks to the forum, which focuses on China's hi-tech development, were among Ding's first public comments on the issue since his promotion in March to oversee the country's development drive.

;

;He also attended the opening ceremony of the National Science and Technology Week in Beijing on May 20, where he inspected displays on the latest in artificial intelligence, integrated circuits, biological medicines and nuclear energy equipment.

;

;Beijing does not officially announce the distribution of work among its vice-premiers, which is only confirmed by the events they attend and the speeches they deliver.

;

;Ding Xuexiang joins party's top decision-making body

;

;A former chief of staff to President Xi Jinping, Ding is now the sixth-ranking member in the powerful seven-man Politburo Standing Committee. At 59, he is also its youngest member.

;

;Ding is the most senior Chinese official to oversee the country's technology development, with the role traditionally given to a lower-ranking vice-premier in the State Council, China's cabinet.

;

;Beijing's previous point man on the technology drive was Liu He, who also oversaw industrial policies, finance regulation and the trade talks with the Donald Trump administration during his tenure from 2018 to March this year.

;

;Neither Liu nor his predecessor Liu Yandong (no relation) – who held the role between 2013 to 2018 and also oversaw education, cultural affairs and public health policies – were members of the Politburo Standing Committee, the pinnacle of the Communist Party's power structure.

;

;Beijing is overhauling its approach to science and technology as it seeks to speed up progress in the sector in response to efforts by Washington and its allies to tighten controls on China's access to advanced technologies.

;

;China's Communist Party to take science and tech reins to break US containment

;

;Ding's appointment to lead the changes coincided with the Communist Party's plan – also announced in March – to put the sector directly under its watch with the creation of a party organ set to improve “centralised and unified leadership” of “science and technology work”.

;

;Alfred Wu, an associate professor at the National University of Singapore, said the decision to put Ding in the driving seat of China's technology innovation underlined Xi's determination for the sector.

;

;“It is different from previous practice. We can now make a conclusion that Ding Xuexiang is more important [than his predecessors in the role], and technology is now more important [than before],” Wu said.

;

;China earmarks 2 per cent budget boost for science and technology

;

;Before serving as Xi's chief of staff from 2017 until his latest promotion, Ding spent two decades in various positions overseeing party affairs in Shanghai and Beijing.

;

;But he initially trained as a materials scientist, earning his first degree in forge pressing from the Northeast China Heavy Machinery Institute in Qiqihar, the second-largest city in the northeast province of Heilongjiang.

;

;After graduation, Ding spent 17 years at the Shanghai Research Institute of Materials, first as a researcher and eventually as its director.

;

;Ding is also understood to have taken over as China's top climate change official, following Han Zheng's promotion to vice-president in the March reshuffle.

;

;Additional reporting by Hayley Wong

; Sat, 27 May 2023 06:20:01 +0800 Winnie the Pooh is teaching Texas kids how to survive school shootings – and parents are upsethttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3222009/winnie-pooh-teaching-texas-kids-how-survive-school-shootings-and-parents-are-upset?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.27 06:02;
;;

;Cindy Campos' five-year-old son was so excited about the Winnie the Pooh book he got at school that he asked her to read it with him as soon as he got home. But her heart sank when she realised it was a tutorial about what to do when “danger is near”, advising children to lock the doors, turn off the lights and quietly hide.

;

;As they read the Stay Safe book the school sent home without explanation or a warning to parents, she began crying, leaving her son confused.

;

;“It's hard because you're reading them a bedtime story and basically now you have to explain in this cute way what the book is about, when it's not exactly cute,” Campos said.

;

;She said her first-grader, who goes to the same junior school as her pre-K son, also got a copy of the book last week. After posting about it in an online neighbourhood group, she found other concerned parents whose children had also brought the book home.

;

;The district's decision to send children home with the book has made waves. California's Democratic governor, Gavin Newsom, tweeted: “Winnie the Pooh is now teaching Texas kids about active shooters because the elected officials do not have the courage to keep our kids safe and pass common sense gun safety laws.”

;

;It sparked enough of a reaction to warrant an explanation from the Dallas Independent School District, which said in a statement on Friday that it works “hard every day to prevent school shootings” by dealing with online threats and improving security measures. It also conducts active shooter drills.

;

;“Recently a booklet was sent home so parents could discuss with their children how to stay safe in such cases,” the district said. “Unfortunately, we did not provide parents any guide or context. We apologise for the confusion and are thankful to parents who reached out to assist us in being better partners.”

;

;The district did not say how many schools and grades in the district received the books.

;

;Frequent shootings put US mass killings on a record pace

;

;Campos said the book was “haunting” her and that it seemed especially “tone deaf” to send it home with children without explanation around the time the state was marking the anniversary of last year's mass shooting at an junior school in Uvalde, when a gunman killed 19 children and two teachers.

;

;It also comes as Texas' Republican-controlled legislature wraps up a session in which it rejected virtually all proposals to tighten gun laws but did pass legislation banning school libraries from having books that contain descriptions, illustrations or audio depicting sexual conduct not relevant to the required school curriculum.

;

;Active shooter drills have become common in American schools, though there is disagreement over whether they do more harm than good.

;

;Campos said that although she does not disagree with the book's intent, she wished it would have come with a warning to parents so that she could introduce it to her children at the right time and in the right way. She said she has discussed school shootings with her children, and that she might have chosen to wait to read them the book until there was another attack.

;

;“I would have done it on my own time,” said Campos, who first spoke to the Oak Cliff Advocate.

;

;The book's cover says: “If there is danger, let Winnie the Pooh and his crew show you what to do.” Inside, it includes passages such as “If danger is near, do not fear. Hide like Pooh does until the police appear. Doors should be locked and the passage blocked. Turn off the light to stay out of sight.”

;

;The book was published by Praetorian Consulting, a Houston-based firm that provides safety, security and crisis management training and services. The company, which did not respond to messages seeking comment, says on its website that it uses age-appropriate material to teach the concepts of “run, hide, fight” – the approach authorities say civilians should take in active shooter situations.

;

;The company also says on its website that its K-6 curriculum features the characters of Winnie the Pooh, which are now in the public domain and even featured in a recent horror film.

; Sat, 27 May 2023 06:20:01 +0800 Why India will continue to lag behind China as a global economic powerhttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3221803/why-india-will-continue-lag-behind-china-global-economic-power?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.27 06:15;
;;

;Over a 40-year career trying to understand the dynamics behind the extraordinary emergence of Asia's economies, perhaps only one question has attracted more debate than whether or when mainland China will attack Taiwan: why has India always lagged behind China, and is that about to change?

;

;The issue has erupted afresh in part because the United Nations says India last month overtook China as the world's most populous nation. It has also been driven by India's strong recent economic growth, and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's efforts to project India as a leader of the Global South. India's chairmanship of the Group of 20 this year, and its hosting of the G20 summit in New Delhi in September, has also prompted chatter about India's rise.

;

;But a further factor has been America's remorseless efforts to slow China's rise, and to reduce the ever-widening range of Chinese goods on which US manufacturers and consumers have come to rely. Every attempt to devise a credible decoupling, diversification or derisking strategy points Joe Biden's team inevitably to India – the only economy with a big enough market and workforce to develop the economies of scale needed to have a hope of competing against China.

;

;But India, for more than 40 years, has remained a miracle about to happen. Back in the 1980s, along with thousands of other Western companies, my then-employer the Financial Times was wrestling with how best to focus its Asian expansion plans: prioritise Hong Kong, focused on the China market, or in Mumbai, focused on India?

;

;For FT bosses, the answer was obvious: India was the world's largest English-speaking market, the world's most populous democracy, and home to one of the world's largest equity markets. It also had long-standing links with Britain.

;

;Arguments that China's leadership was far more pragmatic and seriously committed to opening up to international trade and investment, with the foundations of an urban-industrial psychology that contrasted with India's profoundly rural-agrarian mindset, were brushed aside. To the best of my knowledge, the FT is still battling to publish in India.

;

;My deep doubt that India can become a top-table power that might serve as a democratic counterweight to China was forged in the 1970s by social scientist Barrington Moore's Social Origins of Dictatorship and Democracy.

;

;In asking why India failed to succumb to a Marxist revolution after independence in 1947, while China emerged under Mao Zedong as a radically transformed Marxist power, Moore identified a wide range of powerful inertial forces in India that prevented revolution and shackled economic change – and continue to do so even today.

;

;Perhaps most important were the rural power structures cemented around caste, which still exert more influence over social and economic development than most economists recognise.

;

;In China, revolution swept away ancient power structures, entrenched corrupt networks and ossified vested interests. Corrupt networks could regrow but the inertial undergrowth that had for a century choked change in China had been cleared, opening the country to a potential for change.

;

;The absence of revolution in India left in place existing power structures and long-standing vested interests, along with the corruption they nurtured, blocking the radical political or economic changes that turbocharged China's economic growth from the late 1970s. Corruption remains a scourge in India and a nagging obstacle to growth.

;

;There is magical thinking among forecasters who talk of an “Indian century”, with Modi's India set to overtake China, not simply in population but as a dynamo for global growth.

;

;Alok Sheel, a former secretary of India's Economic Advisory Council, injected some much-needed realism: “If India were to grow at the very optimistic, and currently unlikely, rate of 9 per cent going forward, and China were to slow down to 4 per cent, the Indian economy would be 70 per cent of China's size by mid-century.”

;

;So many factors sit in the way of sustainable strong growth in India. Nearly 43 per cent of the population works in the farming sector, compared to 25 per cent in China. Underemployment, much of it informal and undocumented, hampers any pathway to higher productivity.

;

;India is far from ready to take China's place in the global economy

;

;While India's education spending is higher than in China (as a percentage of government expenditure), literacy remains at 74 per cent, compared with 97 per cent in China, with almost 27 per cent of India's population lacking any formal education. Women account for a large share of the illiterate, contributing to the reality that just 19 per cent of women participate in the workforce, compared with 61 per cent in China.

;

;A failure to spend adequately on education, health, social welfare and other key infrastructure also shackles progress. Just 46 per cent of Indians have access to safe sanitation (compared with 70 per cent in China), and only 43 per cent have access to the internet (70 per cent in China).

;

;One can juggle data ad nauseam, but the reality of the past 40 years remains unchanged: Indian progress is welcome but slow, and the country will continue to lag behind China.

;

;The rising economic heft of the Global South will give India a seat at top tables like the G20, but there is no way Biden can magically think away the reality of China as a global economic force. The 21st century may not be India's century, but it is almost certainly Asia's century, and Washington needs to come to terms with that.
